content:
• Wednesday, November 21, 2018
  • GPRO

    After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GPRO +1.5%. XXII +1.1%.
    • Losers: QD -3.4%. KOS -3.0%. EDIT -1.7%. CZZ -1.7%. UGP -1.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM | 8 Comments
  • DXCM

    Dexcom files prospectus to offer 3.87M shares

    • Dexcom (NASDAQ:DXCM) has filed a prospectus to offer up to 3.866M shares of stock, which could be issued pursuant to its license amendment with Alphabet's Verily.
    • The Verily amendment provided for Dexcom to make an initial payment of up to $250M in stock, to be followed by milestone payments of up to $280M.
    • Dexcom is down 1.9% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM
  • SSL

    Sasol sees stronger half-year profit, cash flow on higher oil prices

    • Sasol (SSL +2.9%) is solidly higher after saying it expects to report headline earnings growth of 12%-29%, or R2.12-R5.12/share, during the six months ending Dec. 31, underpinned by higher Brent crude oil and product prices, and a weaker average rand exchange rate.
    • SSL also forecasts an 80%-100% increase in net income during the current six-month period, equal to R9.03-R11.29/share.
    • "Our underlying cash flow performance and earnings are expected to be much stronger than the period ended December 31 2017," SSL says, adding that a "satisfactory performance of its global assets" also lifted earnings.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 5 Comments
  • AAPL

    Apple considered streaming dongle; ROKU -1.7%

    • Apple (AAPL -0.1%) considered a connected TV dongle for its upcoming streaming service, according to The Information sources.
    • The company had internal discussions about the low-priced streaming device that would compete with Amazon's Fire Stick and Google's Chromecast.
    • A cheaper device would make the streaming service, which launches next year to Apple devices, accessible to a wider audience.
    • Previously: The Information: Apple could bundle services into one subscription (June 28)
    • Roku (NASDAQ:ROKU) shares drop 1.7% on the news.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 62 Comments
  • DE

    Deere +3% despite earnings, revenue misses as investors expected worse

    • Deere (DE +2.9%) enjoys nice gains even after both its top- and bottom-line Q3 results missed estimates and the company offered an underwhelming outlook for 2019, but investors apparently were braced for something worse amid the U.S. trade slowdown with China.
    • DE forecasts FY 2019 equipment sales to grow just 7% Y/Y vs. a 29% jump in FY 2018, but investors cheer projected improvements in gross margins as well as the forecast for a flat to 5% increase in industry sales of agricultural equipment next year in North America, its biggest market.
    • "We would argue the FY19 guidance big picture is better than headlines imply," Baird analysts say.
    • Baird's Mig Dobre rates the stock at Outperform with a $165 price target, and notes "any positive developments on trade down the line could provide potential upside."
    • CFRA's Elizabeth Vermillion reiterates her Hold rating and $158 price target on DE shares, seeing FY 2019 sales growth of 10% on equipment sales growth of 7%, "aided by an ongoing replacement cycle for machinery despite global trade tension."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM | 4 Comments
  • ANY

    Sphere 3D -29% after regaining Nasdaq compliance

    • Sphere 3D (NASDAQ:ANY) announces receiving a Nasdaq notice that it regained compliance with the minimum bid price requirement.
    • ANY shares are down 28.8% to $4.70.
    • Previously: Sphere 3D receives Nasdaq letter, changes CEO (Nov. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM
  • LEN

    Homebuilders get some support from economic data

    • Homebuilding stocks advance as U.S. mortgage rates slip 13 basis points to 4.81%, easing back from the 5.00% mark and the biggest dip in almost four years.
    • There was also some good news in the October existing-home sales number, which rose for the first time in seven months, perhaps indicating an uptick in demand.
    • Also in that report: The rise in home prices is slowing. Combine that with some recent reports that the Fed may pause its steady, gradual rate hike path and you have a slightly brighter outlook for the housing industry.
    • It has been a rough year for the sector.  YTD, ITB is down 29% vs. the S&P 500 Index -0.5% in the same period.
    • Indeed, the National Association Realtor Chief Economist Lawrence Yun asks the Fed to consider the housing market in its decisions: "The Federal Reserve should, therefore, re-evaluate its monetary policy of tightening credit, especially in light of softening inflationary pressures, to help ease the financial burden on potential first-time buyers and assure a slump in the market causes no lasting damage to the economy."
    • iShares U.S. Home Construction ETF's (BATS:ITB) gain of 2.0% includes homebuilders Lennar (LEN +1.5%), D.R. Horton (DHI +2.9%), NVR Inc. (NVR +1.4%), PulteGroup (PHM +1.3%), Taylor Morrison Homes (TMHC +4%), and Toll Brothers (TOL +3.2%). It also includes home-improvement retailers Home Depot (HD +0.4%) and Lowe's (LOW +2.9%) as well as paintmaker Sherwin-Williams (SHW +0.2%).
    • Among other rising homebuilder stocks: KB Home (KBH +3.2%), Beazer Homes (BZH +5.7%), TRI Pointe Homes (TPH +0.9%), and William Lyon Homes (WLH +4.3%).
    • Previously: U.S. mortgage rates slip to lowest since October (Nov. 21)
    • Previously: Existing home sales squeaks past estimate (Nov. 21)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:28 PM | 5 Comments
  • DAKT

    Daktronics up 12% post Q2 beats

    • Daktronics (DAKT +11.7%) gains 12% on Q2 results that beat EPS and revenue estimates with $0.01 and $2.95M respectively.
    • Product order backlog at the end of the Q219 was $150M, compared to a backlog of $155M a year earlier and $177M at the end of the Q119.
    • Orders for the Q2 increased 6.4% (Y/Y).
    • Reece Kurtenbach, chairman, president and CEO: "As we enter into the second half of our fiscal year, we remain optimistic about our long-term outlook. Our portfolio of innovative products and technologies positioned us to capitalize on the growing market demand for digital canvases. In the short term, the current global tariff and trade environment has created cost headwinds on commodity and components used in the production of our solutions"
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 3:25 PM
  • LOW

    Argus lowers Lowe's target

    • Argus analyst Chris Graja maintains a Buy rating on Lowe's (NYSE:LOW) but drops the price target by $10 to $110.
    • Graja reduces his FY20 EPS estimate from $6.40 to $6.00 to reflect "the possibility of more inventory repositioning and more investments in staffing and systems to bolster operations and pave the way for profitable growth."
    • Lowe's shares are up 3.2% to $88.89.
    • Previously: Lowe’s bounces 3% despite Stifel downgrade (Nov. 21)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM | 2 Comments
  • CYAD

    Celyad +7% as lead CAR-T drug candidate shows no toxicity in safety tests

    • Celyad (CYAD +7.2%) surges after disclosing the first patient treated with its CYAD-101 drug candidate showed no toxicity during a safety and anti-tumor activity study of its lead non-gene edited, allogeneic CAR-T clinical candidate.
    • CYAD says the trial was authorized by the FDA under an investigational new drug application that took effect in July.
    • The company also says it ended the September quarter with €55.9M ($63.7M) in cash and equivalents and short-term investments.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:08 PM | 2 Comments
  • FOX

    MLex: Disney/Fox could get Brazil deal OK in two weeks

    • A speedy process in Brazil means that Disney (DIS +1.7%) could get approval there for its $71B deal with Fox (FOX +1.1%, FOXA +1.3%) within two weeks, MLex Market Insight says.
    • The Tribunal there has its last session of the year scheduled for Dec. 5, and doesn't reconvene again until Jan. 30.
    • But a recommendation there with a satisfactory consent decree already drafted could result in a decision to proceed, MLex says.
    • Even a successful decision could be appealed by third parties. And regulator CADE has until March 18 to issue an initial decision on the deal.
    • Source: Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 3:03 PM | 3 Comments
  • ABIL

    Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3.00 PM

    • Gainers: Ability (NASDAQ:ABIL) +154%. Qudian (NYSE:QD) +24%. QAD (NASDAQ:QADA) +20%. Cool Holdings (NASDAQ:AWSM) +19%. Sigma Labs (NASDAQ:SGLB) +14%.
    • Losers: Sphere 3D (NASDAQ:ANY) -22%. 21Vianet Group (NASDAQ:VNET) -10%. Castlight Health (NYSE:CSLT) -9%. Quantum Corporation (NYSE:QTM-OLD) -7%. Windstream Holdings (NASDAQ:WIN) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:01 PM
  • LOW

    Lowe’s bounces 3% despite Stifel downgrade

    • Lowe's (LOW +3.1%) moves out to solid gains despite a Stifel analyst downgrade to Hold from Buy with a $92 price target, slashed from $125, saying the company's disappointing Q3 results indicate higher near-term execution risks with the macro backdrop also unlikely to improve in the near term.
    • Stifel's John Baugh thinks Home Depot (HD +0.9%) "has widened the gap on performance, and it will take some heavy lifting [for Lowe's] to reverse course... At this time we are less confident on the timing management can turn around the company and close the gap with Home Depot in a significant way."
    • Baugh notes Lowe’s online sales of 12% are less than half HD's 28% total, while the timing and certainty of management’s multiple initiatives are uncertain and problems such as out-of-stock items and product assortment remain.
    • Lowe’s CEO Marvin Ellison listed several problems facing the company but said it had plans for fixes, which prompted support from Wells Fargo analysts, who continue to rate the stock Outperform.
    • "While disappointing Q3 results reinforce the view that considerable issues remain, we are still encouraged that the new leadership is setting the stage for a multi-year turnaround," Wells says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM | 3 Comments
  • JNJ

    Johnson & Johnson -3% following negative appeals court ruling on Zytiga

    • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ -3.3%) is today's biggest decliner on the Dow after hitting all-time highs yesterday, after a U.S. appeals court rules JNJ cannot prevent sales of generic Zytiga while the company appeals a trial judge's ruling that invalidated a patent on the prostate cancer medicine.
    • Zytiga amassed $1.4B in U.S. sales during the first nine months of the year, and generic drug makers had expected to begin sales in October.
    • Mylan (MYL -2.5%), Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA +0.8%) and Hikma Pharmaceuticals all have received final approval from the FDA, so the courts are all that is preventing the companies from starting sales; Dr. Reddy’s Labs (RDY) and Amneal Pharmaceuticals (AMRX -0.5%) also want to begin selling copies of the medicine.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM | 25 Comments
  • CRC

    California Resources and Ultra Petroleum among Energy/Material gainers; Zion Oil & Gas and Calumet Specialty Products among the losers

    • Gainers: California Resources (NYSEMKT:CRC) +20%. Ultra Petroleum (NASDAQ:UPL) +12%. Kosmos Energy (NYSE:KOS) +11%. Legacy Reserves (NASDAQ:LGCY) +10%. Berry Petroleum (NASDAQ:BRY) +10%.
    • Losers: Zion Oil & Gas (NASDAQ:ZN) -57%. Calumet Specialty Products Partners (NASDAQ:CLMT) -7%. Sanchez Midstream Partners (NYSEMKT:SNMP) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 9 Comments
  • AMZN

    U.S. online shipping up 17% this season

    • U.S. consumers spent $31.9B shopping online in the first 20 days of this month, up 17% Y/Y, according to Adobe Analytics data.
    • Monday marked the first "$2 billion day of the season" and today is on track to hit $2.1B.
    • The free shipping wars heated up earlier in the month with Amazon (AMZN +2.3%) waving the $25 minimum for non-Prime members and Target (TGT +0.3%) offering free two-day shipping on select items through December 22.
    • Adobe reaffirms its full-season forecast of $124.1B spent online in November and December combined.
    • Other top online retailers: (EBAY +1.2%), (WMT -0.1%), (ETSY +2.4%), (COST -0.6%), (KSS +3.2%).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:19 PM | 34 Comments

  • Tech lunch: Tech recovers from semi slump

    • Another day, another Apple supplier with cuts as Foxconn looks to slash $2.88B in costs including its iPhone unit. But Apple received some better news as an analyst sees the iPhone XR recovering in China unit sales.
    • Overall, the sector (NYSEARCA:XLK) is recovering and up 1.5%. The S&P 500 Index is up 1% and the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 1.3%. The S&P 500 is up 1% and the Nasdaq gains 1.6%.
    • Tomorrow is a U.S. market holiday as Americans celebrate Thanksgiving. Trading resumes Friday for part of the day.
    • Broad tech ETFs: XLK, VGT, SOXL, FDN, SOXX, SMH, GGT, TECL, FTEC, USD, VOX-OLD, IYW, PSI, TDIV, ROM, XSD, QTEC, IYZ, IGV, RYT, SOXS, FNG, TECS, IGM, PSCT, FCOM, FXL, PBS, XNTK, XTL, REW, IGN, PSJ, SSG, PTF, PXQ, XSW, FTXL, LTL, JHMT, XWEB, XITK, XTH, XK, FNGD, FNGU
    • Previously: Apple assembler plans $2.88B in cuts (Nov. 21)
    • Previously: Rosenblatt sees iPhone XR recovery in China (Nov. 21)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:05 PM
  • LMFA

    LM Funding America leads financial gainers; Hexindai and Leju Holdings among losers

    • Gainers: LM Funding America (NASDAQ:LMFA) +18%. EverQuote (NASDAQ:EVER) +15%. China Internet Nationwide Financial Services (NASDAQ:CIFS) +15%. Fanhua (NASDAQ:FANH) +8%. Forestar Group (NYSE:FOR) +8%.
    • Losers: China Rapid Finance (NYSE:XRF) -10%. Grupo Aval Acciones Y Valores S.A. (NYSE:AVAL) -8%. Hexindai (NASDAQ:HX) -6%. Leju Holdings (NYSE:LEJU) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:04 PM | 1 Comment
  • GME

    GameStop to sell Spring Mobile for $700M (updated)

    • GameStop (NYSE:GME) has a definitive deal to sell its Spring Mobile business to Prime Communications, for $700M.
    • Spring Mobile owns and operates 1,289 AT&T wireless stores. The move will fatten GameStop's cash coffers along with sharpening its focus on videogames and collectibles.
    • The move is the result of ongoing review of strategic and financial alternatives, the company says.
    • The deal's expected to close in Q4.
    • Shares were halted for news pending a short bit ago; they were up 2.5% at the time.
    • Updated 1:08 p.m.: Shares have resumed trading and are currently up 12.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:03 PM | 134 Comments
  • GE

    GE debt fears are overblown, analyst says

    • General Electric (GE +2.7%) edges higher as Peter Tchir of Academy Securities argues the market's fears about GE's bonds are overblown.
    • GE shares fell for months before its credit spreads started to widen, which Tchir believes shows "the current concern surrounding the credit can be fixed."
    • "GE should not see a material increase in their total cost of borrowing in 2019, despite spread widening in the secondary markets because of their debt profile," Tchir writes, as ~$26B of the company's $105B of debt is maturing in the next two years, mostly in 2020.
    • Many analysts are worried about the consequences of a potential downgrade of GE's credit to junk; it is the world's no. 6 most indebted non-financial company, big enough to shake the entire debt market.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 151 Comments
  • ABIL

    Microcaps tops list of midday movers

    • Gainers: Ability (NASDAQ:ABIL) +171%.  Inpixon (NASDAQ:INPX) +36%. LM Funding America (NASDAQ:LMFA) +24%. Cool Holdings (NASDAQ:AWSM) +23%. MER Telemanagement Solutions (NASDAQ:MTSL) +20%. California Resources (NYSEMKT:CRC) +19%. Qudian (NYSE:QD) +18%. Kiniksa Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:KNSA) +18%. Tandem Diabetes Care (NASDAQ:TNDM) +17%. Beacon Roofing Supply (NASDAQ:BECN) +17%.
    • Losers: Zion Oil & Gas (NASDAQ:ZN) -58%. Heat Biologics(NASDAQ:HTBX) -31%. Sphere 3D (NASDAQ:ANY) -25%. Aquestive Therapeutics (NASDAQ:AQST) -24%. Onconova Therapeutics(NASDAQ:ONTX) -13%. Air Industries (NYSEMKT:AIRI) -13%. Bioblast Pharma (NASDAQ:ORPN) -12%. China Rapid Finance Limited (NYSE:XRF) -10%. Lantronix (NASDAQ:LTRX) -10%. Eyenovia EYEN) -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM
  • CMCM

    Cheetah Mobile +9.4% after reporting quarterly revenue growth

    • Cheetah Mobile (NYSE:CMCM) is up 9.4% after beating on top and bottom lines in its Q3 earnings, with double-digit revenue growth both sequentially and year-over-year.
    • Gross profit rose 22% to 970.3M yuan (about $141.3M), with gross margin expanding to 71.8% from a year-ago 68%.
    • Attributable net income, meanwhile, rose nearly 20% to 167M yuan ($24.3M).
    • Revenues were up 15.6%, and rose 22.5% from the previous quarter, to 1.352B yuan (about $196.9M).
    • Mobile entertainment revenues rose 37.5% (and 49.6% sequentially) to 497.9M yuan; revenues from utility products and related services rose 4.4% to 835.6M yuan.
    • In operations, global mobile monthly active users was 535M; overseas markets accounted for 68% of those. As for China mobile MAUs, they grew 18% Y/Y and 6% Q/Q, to 171M.
    • Cash from operations was 338.8M (about $49.3M); free cash flow came to 326.3M yuan ($47.5M).
    • For Q4, it's guiding to revenues of 1.39B-1.43B yuan (about $202M-$208M, vs. $206.9M consensus).
    • Earnings call transcript
    • Previously: Cheetah Mobile beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (Nov. 21 2018)
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM
  • PCG

    Fitch downgrades Berkshire, NextEra solar farms as PG&E credit tumbles

    • PG&E’s (PCG +3.9%) pain is spreading to some of the power plants to whom it sells electricity, as Fitch Ratings downgrades the debt of two solar farms in California on concern about the utility's finances.
    • PG&E, which was downgraded last week, is the sole electricity customer for Berkshire Hathaway Energy's (BRK.A, BRK.B) 550 MW Topaz Solar Farms and NextEra Energy's (NYSE:NEE) 250 MW Genesis Solar.
    • Fitch now rates the $958M outstanding on Topaz’s senior secured notes and the $140M in Genesis’s series B trust certificates at BBB-, just above junk, down from BBB; the ratings agency downgrades Topaz in September, also because of a downgrade to PG&E.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:30 PM | 25 Comments
  • EIX

    Edison International upgraded to Buy at Mizuho after liability analysis

    • Edison International (EIX +1.6%) is higher after Mizuho upgrades shares to Buy from Neutral while lowering its stock price target to $57.50 from $62.
    • Citing an analysis of the company's 2017-18 wildfire and mudslide liabilities, Mizuho analyst Paul Fremont estimates "more upside opportunity than downside opportunity" from current stock levels.
    • The analyst's after-tax and after-insurance base case liability estimate is $3.3B for the 2017-18 wildfires and mudslides.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:22 PM | 2 Comments

  • Natural gas inventory draw was more than expected in the last week

    • EIA Natural Gas Inventory: -134 Bcf vs. -105 Bcf consensus, +39 Bcf last week.
    • Futures +0.71% to $4.555.
    • ETFs: UNG, DGAZ, UGAZ, BOIL, KOLD, UNL
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM | 65 Comments
  • FL

    Foot Locker leads consumer gainers and Caleres the only loser

    • Gainers: Foot Locker (NYSE:FL) +17%. Dogness (NASDAQ:DOGZ) +15%. BRF S.A. (NYSE:BRFS) +7%. Pyxus International (NYSE:PYX) +7%. Thor Industries (NYSE:THO) +7%.
    • Losers: Caleres (NYSE:CAL) -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 1 Comment
  • TI

    Ex-CEO of Telecom Italia blasts Singer as 'raider'

    • The ex-CEO of Telecom Italia (TI +2%) has lambasted Paul Singer of Elliott Management, the firm that has wrested control of the Italian incumbent telecom, after his removal from the company.
    • Amos Genish was replaced by the board while he was away on business last week, with Elliott-backed director Luigi Gubitosi taking his place. Genish had been backed by France's Vivendi (VIVHY +2.1%), which lost control of the board in a tense fight.
    • Now Genish calls Singer a "raider" and has charged him with lying about his intentions for the company. Singer said in April he wouldn't push for a break-up, but reversed position after Elliott took control, Genish says.
    • The selection of Gubitosi leads observers to expect a split of TI into a "ServiceCo" and a "NetCo," the latter of which would contain the fixed network of which TI could sell a majority.
    • Vivendi is reportedly mulling its legal options in the wake of Genish's removal.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:45 AM
  • INVVY

    Indivior -12% after court lifts injunction against Suboxone generic

    • Indivior PLC (OTCPK:INVVY) sinks 12% after a U.S. appeals court vacates a preliminary injunction that had prevented Dr. Reddy's Laboratories (RDY +0.7%) from selling a generic version of Suboxone, Indivior's product that used to treat opioid dependence.
    • Without the preliminary injunction, Indivior assumes that Dr. Reddy's will resume its launch of generic buprenorphine/naloxone sublingual film product in the U.S. However, the exact timing for its re-introduction isn't known, says Indivior.
    • Indivior says it will oppose Dr. Reddy's motion requesting the court to either issue a mandate returning the case to the district court or stay the preliminary injunction pending the issuance of the mandate.
    • INVVY's FY2018 guidance for net revenue of $990M-$1.02B and net income of $230M-$255M remains valid unless a generic product is introduced in 2018.
    • Previously: Dr. Reddy announces favorable outcome in buprenorphine and naloxone sublingual film patent litigation (Nov. 21)
    • Previously: Court denies Dr. Reddy's stay on generic Suboxone ruling (July 18)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:44 AM
  • BIOYF

    BioSyent -5.5% post Q3 results

    • BioSyent (OTCPK:BIOYF -5.5%) reports Q3 revenue decrease of 3% Y/Y to C$5.26M.
    • Canadian Pharmaceutical net revenues of C$4.71M increased by 11% Y/Y and International Pharmaceutical net revenues of C$0.28M decreased by 51% Y/Y.
    • EBITDA of C$1.73M decreased by 1% Y/Y & net income after tax of C$1.27M decreased by 2% Y/Y.
    • The Company had cash, equivalents, and short term investments totalling C$22.6M.
    • Total Shareholders’ Equity increased to $26.6M.
    • Return on Equity for the Trailing 12 months ended September 30, 2018 was 24%.
    • Previously: BioSyent reports Q3 results (Nov. 21 2018)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM
  • X

    WTO to set up panels to rule on U.S. tariff disputes; steelmakers rise

    • Steelmakers get a boost after the World Trade Organization says it will investigate the legality of U.S. tariffs on steel and aluminum imports based on national security concerns.
    • “Infringing on a sovereign’s right to determine, for itself, what is in its own essential security interests would run exactly contrary to the WTO reforms that are necessary in order for this organization to maintain any relevancy,” says a U.S. official.
    • Other countries disagree, saying the U.S. tariffs are thinly disguised protectionism that damages rivals globally.
    • Among relevant tickers: X +2.6%, MT +2.8%, NUE +1.7%, AKS +3.3%, CMC +2.2%.
    • ETF: SLX
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM | 8 Comments
  • FB

    Facebook appeals £500K fine in Britain over data scandal

    • Facebook (FB +2.8%) is appealing a fine of £500,000 (about $639K) it received from UK regulators over the Cambridge Analytica scandal.
    • The company says the fine was based on UK Information Commissioner's Officer concerns that the incident affected the data of British citizens.
    • The ICO just wrapped an investigation and hasn't found evidence that British data were passed to Cambridge Analytica. “Therefore, the core of the ICO’s argument no longer relates to the events involving Cambridge Analytica."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:04 AM | 12 Comments
  • RSLS

    Medical equipment leads Healthcare gainers; while biotechnology among the losers

    • Gainers: ReShape Lifesciences (OTC:RSLS) +13%. Tandem Diabetes Care (NASDAQ:TNDM) +12%. Motus GI (NASDAQ:MOTS) +11%. Microbot Medical (NASDAQ:MBOT) +10%. Invacare (NYSE:IVC) +10%.
    • Losers: Heat Biologics (NASDAQ:HTBX) -31%. Aquestive Therapeutics (NASDAQ:AQST) -24%. Bioblast Pharma (NASDAQ:ORPN) -15%. Eyenovia (NASDAQ:EYEN) 3%. Aduro BioTech (NASDAQ:ADRO) -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM | 2 Comments
  • NYRSF

    Nyrstar wins $650M cash lifeline from Trafigura

    • Nyrstar (OTC:NYRSF +16.2%) receives a $650M cash injection from its Trafigura, its largest shareholder, a lifeline that analysts say should alleviate some of the short-term pressure on the zinc producer and make a debt restructuring more likely in the future.
    • "The liquidity situation seems very critical and this is indeed a lifeline," says ABN Amro's Philip Ngotho. "For the zinc market, this is good. But for bondholders and shareholders, it doesn’t really change the story."
    • Nyrstar bonds plunge after Trafigura said the money cannot be used to repay debt.
    • With the rescue, Trafigura is helping to ensure that Nyrstar can keep zinc supply flowing under its supply deal, and it may have a claim to key assets in the event of a default, giving it a leg up on other creditors.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM | 1 Comment
  • CSLT

    Castlight Health -11% amid insider sales

    • Castlight Health (NYSE:CSLT) has seen a small exodus from insider holders in the C-suite this week, according to SEC filings.
    • New Form 4s show sales by CEO John Doyle (of 18,519 shares); by Chief Financial Officer Siobhan Mangini (of 13,997 shares); and by Chief Accounting Officer Eric Chan (of 7,406 shares), among others.
    • Those three added up to 39,922 share sales over the past week, with more than $147,000 worth being sold overall.
    • Shares are down 11.1% this morning.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:54 AM | 1 Comment
  • CCL

    Bernstein sees lodging names as undervalued

    • Bernstein is out with a recommendation on the lodging sector as it sees an "anti-bubble" on the valuation front.
    • Analyst David Beckel points to cruise line stocks Carnival (CCL +1%) and Royal Caribbean (RCL +0.6%) in particular as undervalued compared to fundamentals. Meanwhile, earnings and sentiment on Marriott International (MAR +1.9%) and Hilton Worldwide (HLT +2%) is seen as skewed to the downside.
    • Source: Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 10:49 AM | 1 Comment
  • TYEKF

    Thyssenkrupp mired in the red despite optimistic 2019 forecast

    • Thyssenkrupp (OTCPK:TYEKF -2.3%) is lower after reporting a wider FQ4 net loss but saying it remains cautiously optimistic for the year ahead and issuing new guidance.
    • Thyssenkrupp says Q4 adjusted EBIT from continuing operations totaled €275M, missing a consensus forecast of €324M, citing operational issues and risk provisions at its components unit and high raw materials costs and currency headwinds at its elevator unit; sales rose 3.5% Y/Y to €11.06B from €10.68B.
    • The company targets adjusted EBIT of more than €1B for the 2018-19 financial year, an increase of at least 42% from the €706M reported for 2017-18 and based on the view that nearly all its divisions will show a marked improvement compared with the previous year.
    • But Barclays analysts call the guidance "underwhelming," adding that revenue growth "looks optimistic in light of the current macro backdrop."

  • BHP

    BHP says has learned from past mistakes, promises wiser spending approach

    • BHP (BHP +1.6%) tells investors it has learned the lessons of past mistakes of spending billions of dollars on big ticket deals and new projects, and has the rules in place to make sure it invests wisely in future.
    • Finance chief Peter Beaven says BHP, which has been criticized by activist investor Elliott Advisors for being a poor steward of capital, has been making better investment decisions since the introduction of new spending rules.
    • "We have made significant improvements," Beaven tells an investor briefing in Melbourne. "We have institutionalized our approach to capital allocation. We’ve reduced net debt by $15B. We’ve changed our dividend policy to a more appropriate payout ratio."
    • BHP is more likely to make small acquisitions in early stage assets than big ticket purchases, the CFO says, citing the recent investment in SolGold, a junior exploration company looking to develop a highly prospective copper deposit in Ecuador.
    • BHP faces big spending decisions on the expansion of Olympic Dam, a giant copper mine in South Australia, and development of Jansen, a Canadian potash project; on Jansen, Beaven says it is an attractive asset because it likely would be the lowest cost producer in the world.

    Gap +3% as store closings sized up

    • Gap (NYSE:GPS) is up 3.3% as the company's plan to trim stores steals the headlines from roughly in-line Q3 results.
    • CEO Art Peck laid out the plan during the retailer's conference call (transcript): "There are hundreds of other stores that likely don’t fit our vision for the future of Gap brand specialty store, whether in terms of profitability, customer experience, traffic trends, importantly the ROD structure and/or near and long-term relevance to the brand. These stores are a drag on the health and a drag on the performance of the brand."
    • Despite the efforts at store rationalizaiton, Bank of America Merrill Lynch keeps an Underperform rating on Gap.
    • "We think struggles at Gap and lofty Old Navy goals will make it difficult to meet guidance," warns the BAML analyst team.
    • BAML also points out that there could be "unintended consequences" of rapid store closures at key locations because the stores serve as marketing vehicles for the e-commerce business. Gap management said on the conference call that it would address the "bottom half" of its store portfolio for the Gap brand and look to minimize costs associated with any closings.
    • Also weighing in on the Gap plan is Cowen. "We view management’s comment on addressing the bottom half of the Gap’s specialty store base as encouraging if executed right," notes analyst Oliver Chen.

  • CHK

    U.S. natural gas jumps as below-normal stockpiles seen shrinking

    • Nymex December natural gas +2.6% to $4.641/MMBtu as U.S. stockpiles, already at the lowest seasonal level in 15 years, are forecast to drop by more than 4x the five-year average.
    • Prices last week skyrocketed to the highest in more than four years as cold weather stoked concerns of a supply crunch.
    • Inventories probably slipped 108B cf last week, according to the median of nine analyst estimates compiled by Bloomberg, compared with the five-year average drop of 25B cf; the EIA will issue its weekly report today due to the Thanksgiving Day holiday.
    • Inventories are at the lowest for this time of year since 2003, and are 16% below the five-year average and 14% below year-earlier levels.
    • Colder-than-usual temperatures are expected across parts of central and eastern U.S. during Nov. 26-30.
    • In pre-market trade: CHK +3.7%, EQT +1.1%, SWN +0.6%.
    • ETFs: UNG, UGAZ, DGAZ, BOIL, GASL, FCG, KOLD, UNL, GASX, DCNG, GAZB

    Synthetic Biologics announces positive outcome of meeting with FDA on SYN-004 development; shares up 25% premarket

    • Synthetic Biologics (NYSEMKT:SYN) is up 25% after successfully completing an End-of-Phase 2 meeting with the FDA to discuss development of SYN-004 (ribaxamase) for the prevention of antibiotic-mediated Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).
    • Pursuant to the meeting, the FDA has proposed criteria for Phase 3 clinical efficacy and safety which, if achieved, may support submission for marketing approval of ribaxamase on the basis of a single Phase 3 clinical trial. Final agreement on these criteria is contingent on FDA evaluation of a detailed Phase 3 clinical trial protocol.
    • The primary efficacy endpoint of the trial will be the reduction in the incidence of CDI at one month after the last drug dose versus placebo.
    • Synthetic Biologics anticipates initiating the trial after securing additional potential financing via a strategic partnership.
